original_period_characterizations.topic_description: During 1973-1989, deep_learning research focused on developing foundational methods for automated analysis of complex data. This period was characterized by the emergence of neural network-based approaches in image processing and computer vision tasks, including face recognition and zip code classification. Notable work included \"Textural Features for Image Classification\" (1973) which explored statistical feature extraction from images, laying groundwork for automated visual pattern analysis. Similarly, \"Understanding Face Recognition\" (1986) demonstrated early neural network applications in recognizing complex biological structures like human faces.

representative_papers.title: Understanding face recognition
representative_papers.abstract:
This article presents a theoretical model for understanding face recognition, outlining seven distinct types of information derived from faces and exploring the cognitive processes involved in recognizing familiar faces. It integrates findings from various studies, including laboratory experiments and observations of individuals with cerebral injuries, to clarify the similarities and differences between face recognition and other forms of recognition, such as object and word recognition.

Topic: pattern recognition, computer science, machine learning, face recognition, image analysis, information fusion, feature detection, cognitive science, data science, image representation, computational imaging, deep learning, machine learning research, machine vision, face detection, object recognition, feature extraction, automatic identification, computer vision

representative_papers.title: Backpropagation Applied to Handwritten Zip Code Recognition
representative_papers.abstract:
This article explores the application of backpropagation in a neural network architecture to improve the recognition of handwritten zip code digits for the U.S. Postal Service, highlighting how task-specific constraints enhance the network's ability to generalize and accurately classify characters from normalized images.

Topic: pattern recognition, computer science, natural language processing, character recognition, text recognition, machine learning, deep learning, automatic classification, zip code recognition

representative_papers.title: The CES-D Scale
representative_papers.abstract:
The CES-D Scale is a validated self-report tool designed to assess depressive symptoms in the general population, demonstrating high internal consistency and reliability across diverse demographic groups. Its effectiveness for epidemiological studies is supported by strong correlations with other depression measures and clinical ratings.

Topic: full duplex, scaling analysis, measurement, complex event processing, neuroscience, machine learning, unified classification, deep learning, planetary sciences, full-scale measurement, ces-d scale, neurology

representative_papers.title: Textural Features for Image Classification
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the significance of textural features in image classification across various types of imagery, including photomicrographs and satellite images. It presents easily computable textural features based on gray-tone spatial dependencies and demonstrates their effectiveness in categorizing images, achieving high identification accuracy across different datasets.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, computational imaging, content-based image retrieval, image classification, object recognition, computer vision, multimedia retrieval, feature detection, deep learning, image representation, machine learning research, texture analysis, textural features, machine vision, digital image processing

representative_papers.title: Petri nets: Properties, analysis and applications
representative_papers.abstract:
The article provides a comprehensive overview of Petri nets, including their historical context, modeling examples, and various analytical methods. It explores subclasses such as marked graphs and discusses applications in fields like computer science and systems biology, while also highlighting recent advancements in reachability criteria and stochastic performance modeling.

Topic: complex system, computer science, systems biology, stochastic petri net, applied mathematics, petri net, modeling and simulation, network analysis, deep learning, neural network (machine learning)

original_period_characterizations.topic_label: Deep Learning for Pattern Recognition in Computer Vision
original_period_characterizations.topic_description: During the 1990-1994 period, deep learning research was characterized by intense exploration of neural networks for pattern recognition tasks. The publication "Neural Networks for Pattern Recognition" (1994) exemplifies this focus on supervised learning algorithms applied to complex data analysis problems in image processing. Simultaneously, studies like "Eigenfaces for Recognition" (1991) demonstrated the viability of dimensionality reduction techniques such

representative_papers.title: C4.5: Programs for Machine Learning
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses "C4.5: Programs for Machine Learning," a comprehensive guide by Ross Quinlan that details the C4.5 algorithm for classification in machine learning. It covers the implementation of the algorithm, including source code, usage notes, and case studies, while emphasizing its effectiveness in creating decision trees and if-then rules for accurate data classification.

Topic: pattern recognition, computer science, computational learning theory, supervised learning, machine learning tool, machine learning, data science, computational intelligence, deep learning, statistics, knowledge discovery, machine learning research, automatic classification, automated machine learning, data mining

representative_papers.title: Neural networks for pattern recognition
representative_papers.abstract:
This article provides a comprehensive overview of feed-forward neural networks in the context of statistical pattern recognition, covering essential concepts, modeling techniques, error functions, and learning algorithms. It serves as a valuable resource for those in fields such as computer science, machine learning, and data science, featuring over 100 exercises to enhance understanding.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, convolutional neural network, neural architecture search, machine learning, recurrent neural network, sparse neural network, cognitive science, temporal pattern recognition, data science, computational intelligence, deep learning, neural networks, machine learning research, neural network (machine learning), machine vision

representative_papers.title: Eigenfaces for Recognition
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the development of a near-real-time facial recognition system that utilizes a two-dimensional approach to identify individuals by comparing their facial features to a database of known faces, leveraging eigenfaces as a method for efficient image representation and recognition. The system is designed to operate effectively within practical performance requirements and can learn new features in an unsupervised manner using neural network architecture.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, computational imaging, character recognition, machine learning, applied mathematics, data science, spectral theory, deep learning, image representation, machine learning research, facial recognition system, human identification, machine vision, digital image processing, facial expression recognition, face detection

representative_papers.title: The rapid generation of mutation data matrices from protein sequences
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents an efficient method for generating mutation data matrices from large protein sequence datasets using a peptide-based sequence comparison algorithm, enabling rapid clustering and alignment of sequences. This approach allows for the quick processing of extensive databases, such as SWISS-PROT, and updates standard mutation matrices that have not been revised in over a decade.

Topic: mutation data matrices, next-generation sequencing, molecular biology, matrix biology, protein sequences, bioinformatics, systems biology, mutation-based testing, gene expression, biostatistics, computational biology, deep learning, structural bioinformatics, genomics, machine learning research, rapid generation, sequence alignment, protein science, genome biology, sequence analysis, molecular informatics

representative_papers.title: The New Second Generation: Segmented Assimilation and its Variants
representative_papers.abstract:
The article explores the concept of segmented assimilation in the context of the new second generation of immigrants in the United States, highlighting the unique challenges and diverse outcomes they face in adapting to American society. It presents contemporary data and empirical case studies to illustrate the varying modes of incorporation and the resources that influence their integration experiences.

Topic: data science, data assimilation, deep learning, machine learning

original_period_characterizations.topic_label: Deep Learning for Computer Vision Pattern Recognition
original_period_characterizations.topic_description: During the period spanning from 1995 to 1998, deep learning research was primarily focused on advancing neural network-based approaches for pattern recognition tasks in computer vision. This era saw significant contributions such as 'Neural Networks: A Comprehensive Foundation' (1998) and 'Neural Networks for Pattern Recognition' (1995), which provided a thorough mathematical understanding of the field, building upon earlier foundational work like 'Understanding Face Recognition'. Additionally, papers addressing cognitive science aspects and recurrent neural networks, such as 'Bidirectional Recurrent Neural Networks' (1997), highlighted the growing interest in modeling complex data analysis processes. Research on face recognition systems was further examined in 'Human and machine recognition of faces: a survey' (1995), demonstrating how deep learning techniques were being applied to real-world problems like visual attention, thereby solidifying its role as a crucial method for analyzing and interpreting complex sensory information.

representative_papers.title: Neural Networks for Pattern Recognition
representative_papers.abstract:
This book offers a comprehensive exploration of feed-forward neural networks within the context of statistical pattern recognition, covering essential concepts, modeling techniques, and error minimization algorithms. It also addresses key topics such as learning generalization, data processing, and feature extraction, concluding with an extensive discussion on Bayesian applications in neural networks.

Topic: neural networks, pattern recognition, machine vision, neural architecture search, sparse neural network, neural network (machine learning), temporal pattern recognition, cognitive science, computational intelligence, computer science, recurrent neural network, convolutional neural network, machine learning, machine learning research, deep learning, data science, image analysis

representative_papers.title: Neural Networks: A Comprehensive Foundation
representative_papers.abstract:
"Neural Networks: A Comprehensive Foundation" offers an in-depth exploration of neural networks from an engineering perspective, covering essential topics such as learning processes, back-propagation, and VLSI implementation. This well-organized and accessible text is designed for professional engineers and graduate students, featuring practical examples, problems, and illustrations to reinforce key concepts in the field of neural computation and machine learning.

Topic: computer science, machine learning, comprehensive foundation, neural networks, neural computation, deep learning, neural network (machine learning), neuronal network

representative_papers.title: Human and machine recognition of faces: a survey
representative_papers.abstract:
This article provides a comprehensive survey of the literature on human and machine face recognition, highlighting the various applications, technical challenges, and research developments in the field over the past two decades. It emphasizes the lack of collaboration between psychophysics and engineering studies and reviews techniques for face segmentation, feature extraction, and classification methods.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, object recognition, computer vision, machine learning, cognitive science, deep learning, facial recognition system, vision recognition, machine vision, face detection, machine recognition, facial expression recognition

representative_papers.title: A model of saliency-based visual attention for rapid scene analysis
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a visual attention system modeled after primate behavior and neuronal architecture, which creates a topographical saliency map by combining multiscale image features. This system efficiently identifies and selects prominent locations in a scene for rapid analysis, enhancing scene understanding and interpretation in computer vision applications.

Topic: computer science, vision recognition, information fusion, scene analysis, scene interpretation, cognitive science, vision language model, data science, deep learning, pattern recognition, machine learning, computer vision, computational imaging, scene understanding, rapid scene analysis, saliency-based visual attention, machine vision, image analysis, image representation

representative_papers.title: Bidirectional recurrent neural networks
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the development of bidirectional recurrent neural networks (BRNNs), which enhance traditional RNNs by allowing simultaneous training in both forward and backward time directions. It presents experimental results demonstrating that BRNNs outperform other methods in regression classification tasks on artificial data and phoneme recognition from the TIMIT database, while also facilitating efficient estimation of conditional posterior probabilities for complete symbol sequences.

Topic: computer science, machine learning, recurrent neural network, neural computation, computational neuroscience, deep learning, neural network (machine learning)

original_period_characterizations.topic_label: Advancements in Deep Learning for Computer Vision
original_period_characterizations.topic_description: During 1999-2003, deep learning research continued to advance through multiple paradigms including neural networks applied to computer vision tasks. Papers like 'Eigenfaces for Recognition' (1994) were further developed and refined during this period. The focus shifted towards handling challenges such as class imbalance in datasets with the introduction of techniques like SMOTE.

representative_papers.title: SMOTE: Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique (SMOTE) as a method for improving classifier performance on imbalanced datasets, where minority classes are underrepresented. It highlights the effectiveness of combining over-sampling of minority classes with under-sampling of majority classes to enhance sensitivity and achieve better results in classification tasks, particularly in terms of the Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) curve.

Topic: sampling (statistics), sampling, monte carlo sampling, sampling technique, applied statistics, machine learning, data heterogeneity, biostatistics, data science, deep learning, statistics, machine learning research, complex sample, data mining

representative_papers.title: Mean shift: a robust approach toward feature space analysis
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a non-parametric mean shift technique for analyzing complex multimodal feature spaces and identifying arbitrarily shaped clusters. It demonstrates the method's effectiveness through applications in low-level vision tasks, such as image segmentation and discontinuity-preserving smoothing, supported by extensive experimental results.

Topic: pattern recognition, computer science, machine learning, feature space analysis, mean shift, image analysis, information fusion, structure from motion, feature detection, data science, feature (computer vision), computational imaging, robust feature, deep learning, computational statistic, machine learning research, shift detection, machine vision, computer vision, applied mathematics

representative_papers.title: Multiresolution gray-scale and rotation invariant texture classification with local binary patterns
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a novel multiresolution approach for gray-scale and rotation invariant texture classification using local binary patterns, emphasizing the significance of "uniform" patterns in image analysis. It highlights the method's computational efficiency and robustness against variations, supported by experimental results demonstrating effective classification of simple texture patterns.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, image classification, hierarchical classification, computer vision, local binary patterns, multiresolution gray-scale, object categorization, deep learning, texture analysis, machine vision, digital image processing

representative_papers.title: Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems 14
representative_papers.abstract:
The article provides an overview of the proceedings from the 2001 Neural Information Processing Systems (NIPS) Conference, highlighting its interdisciplinary focus on neural computation and the high-quality research presented across various fields such as algorithms, cognitive science, and machine learning. It notes that only about 30 percent of submitted papers were accepted, underscoring the conference's commitment to excellence in the field.

Topic: computer science, artificial intelligence, machine learning, neural science, neural computation, computational intelligence, deep learning, machine learning research, neural network (machine learning), intelligent information processing, neural information

representative_papers.title: <tt>BLAT</tt>—The <tt>BLAST</tt>-Like Alignment Tool
representative_papers.abstract:
The article introduces BLAT, a new alignment tool that significantly enhances the speed and accuracy of mRNA/DNA and cross-species protein alignments in vertebrate genomes, achieving results 500 times faster than existing methods. It details BLAT's innovative use of K-mer indexing and its multi-stage alignment process, while also comparing its performance against other tools and discussing optimization strategies.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, information fusion, sequence analysis, clustering, data science, molecular biology, deep learning, network analysis, signal recognition, sequence alignment, representation analysis, sequence assembly

original_period_characterizations.topic_label: Deep Learning for Computer Vision Pattern Recognition
original_period_characterizations.topic_description: During 2004-2008, research in deep learning was heavily concentrated on enhancing neural network methods for computer vision tasks. Key papers like 'Reducing the Dimensionality of Data with Neural Networks' (2006) and 'A Fast Learning Algorithm for Deep Belief Nets' (2006) exemplified the focus on developing more efficient architectures, while works such as 'Best practices for convolutional neural networks applied to visual document analysis' (2005) showed practical applications in areas like object recognition. This period built upon earlier advancements by refining algorithms and addressing challenges specific to complex data representation and classification.

representative_papers.title: A Fast Learning Algorithm for Deep Belief Nets
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a fast learning algorithm for deep belief networks that utilizes complementary priors to address inference challenges in densely connected networks with multiple hidden layers. By employing a greedy layer-wise training approach and a fine-tuning process, the algorithm effectively models the joint distribution of handwritten digit images and their labels, outperforming traditional discriminative methods in classification tasks.

Topic: computer science, fast learning algorithm, deep belief nets, unsupervised machine learning, machine learning, computational intelligence, deep learning, neural network (machine learning)

representative_papers.title: Reducing the Dimensionality of Data with Neural Networks
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the use of multilayer neural networks, specifically autoencoders, for reducing high-dimensional data to low-dimensional representations, highlighting an effective initialization method that enhances their performance compared to traditional principal components analysis.

Topic: dimensionality reduction, data reduction, machine learning, neural networks, data science, deep learning, machine learning research, nonlinear dimensionality reduction, neural network (machine learning)

representative_papers.title: Best practices for convolutional neural networks applied to visual document analysis
representative_papers.abstract:
This article outlines best practices for applying convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to visual document analysis, emphasizing the importance of training on large datasets and the advantages of using convolutional architectures over fully connected networks. It provides a straightforward implementation approach that avoids complex techniques, demonstrating effective results through examples with MNIST digit images.

Topic: image analysis, computer science, information visualization, convolutional neural network, text recognition, computer vision, machine learning, visualization, best practices, cognitive science, data science, deep learning, image representation, machine learning research, holistic view, machine vision, visual document analysis, visual question answering

representative_papers.title: A performance evaluation of local descriptors
representative_papers.abstract:
This article evaluates the performance of various local descriptors used for image analysis, particularly those extracted by the Harris-Affine detector, by comparing their effectiveness in terms of recall and precision under different viewing conditions. The study highlights the superiority of an extended SIFT descriptor over the original, while also noting that SIFT-based descriptors generally perform best across different detectors, with steerable filters excelling among low-dimensional options.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, machine vision, content-based image retrieval, object recognition, image retrieval, computer vision, object detection, data science, deep learning, image representation, machine learning research, local descriptors, information retrieval, feature (computer vision)

representative_papers.title: PCA-SIFT: a more distinctive representation for local image descriptors
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses PCA-SIFT, an enhanced local image descriptor that improves upon the traditional SIFT algorithm by utilizing principal components analysis (PCA) for more distinctive and robust feature representation. The authors demonstrate that PCA-SIFT offers greater accuracy and efficiency in image retrieval and matching tasks compared to standard SIFT descriptors.

Topic: pattern recognition, computer science, principal component analysis, image analysis, information fusion, local image descriptors, feature detection, data science, image representation, distinctive representation, vision recognition, feature (computer vision), computational imaging, localization, deep learning, machine vision, digital image processing, object recognition, computer vision, geography

original_period_characterizations.topic_description: During 2009-2012, deep learning research focused on feature learning within computer vision tasks. The publication of 'Learning Multiple Layers of Features from Tiny Images' (2009) demonstrated how hierarchical representations could be learned from basic image data. Concurrently, papers like 'Convolutional Deep Belief Networks for Scalable Unsupervised Learning of Hierarchical Representations' (2009) showcased the potential of deep architectures to capture complex patterns in visual data.

representative_papers.title: Learning Multiple Layers of Features from Tiny Images
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the training of a multi-layer generative model for natural images using a dataset of millions of tiny color images, specifically focusing on Restricted Boltzmann Machines (RBMs) and Deep Belief Networks (DBNs) to learn effective image features and improve classification performance compared to raw pixel data. It highlights the challenges faced by previous attempts and emphasizes the use of the CIFAR-10 dataset for labeled image analysis.

Topic: image analysis, computational imaging, computer science, feature learning, computer vision, machine learning, tiny images, feature fusion, multiple layers, data science, knowledge discovery, deep learning, image representation, few-shot learning, machine vision, digital image processing, multiple instance learning

representative_papers.title: Learning Deep Architectures for AI
representative_papers.abstract:
The article explores the role of deep architectures in advancing artificial intelligence, emphasizing their necessity for learning complex functions and high-level abstractions in tasks like vision and language. It discusses recent developments in algorithms and architectures, particularly in the context of neural networks and belief networks, while highlighting the challenges and future directions in this evolving field.

Topic: machine learning, computer science, deep architectures, artificial intelligence, deep learning, ai architecture

representative_papers.title: Convolutional deep belief networks for scalable unsupervised learning of hierarchical representations
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the development of convolutional deep belief networks designed for scalable unsupervised learning of hierarchical representations, enabling effective processing of high-dimensional images. It highlights the model's ability to perform efficient probabilistic inference and learn high-level visual features from unlabeled natural scenes, demonstrating strong performance in various recognition tasks.

Topic: computer science, convolutional neural network, hierarchical classification, neuroscience, machine learning, unsupervised machine learning, hierarchical representations, data science, neural computation, deep learning, machine learning research, neural network (machine learning), scalable unsupervised learning

representative_papers.title: Context-Dependent Pre-Trained Deep Neural Networks for Large-Vocabulary Speech Recognition
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a novel context-dependent deep neural network (CD-DNN-HMM) model for large-vocabulary speech recognition, highlighting its effectiveness in improving accuracy over traditional Gaussian mixture models. Through robust pre-training and optimization techniques, the proposed model demonstrates significant performance enhancements on a challenging business search dataset, achieving notable reductions in error rates.

Topic: computer science, speech recognition, voice recognition, language model, natural language processing, speech processing, spoken language processing, machine learning, cognitive science, data science, language recognition, deep learning, speech communication, large-vocabulary speech recognition, speech technology, spoken language technology, language learning, speech corpus

representative_papers.title: Matrix Factorization Techniques for Recommender Systems
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the advantages of matrix factorization techniques over traditional nearest neighbor methods in recommender systems, highlighting their ability to integrate various types of information, such as implicit feedback and temporal effects, as demonstrated by the Netflix Prize competition.

Topic: computer science, ranking algorithm, machine learning, recommender system, cold-start problem, data science, deep learning, matrix factorization, machine learning research, principal component analysis, information retrieval, matrix factorization techniques, data mining

original_period_characterizations.topic_label: Advancements in Deep Learning for Computer Vision
original_period_characterizations.topic_description: During the period spanning from 2013 to 2016, deep learning experienced substantial advancements primarily focused on improving computer vision tasks. Notable papers such as "Very Deep Convolutional Networks for Large-Scale Image Recognition" (2014) and "Going deeper with convolutions" (2015) exemplify the trend towards creating more complex neural network architectures to enhance feature extraction from visual data, while "Fully convolutional networks for semantic segmentation" (2015) demonstrates another key development in making vision models fully trainable end-to-end. Additionally, papers like "Rich Feature Hierarchies for Accurate Object Detection and Semantic Segmentation" (2014) and "Learning Hierarchical Features for Scene Labeling" (2013) further validate the effectiveness of deep feature hierarchies across various computer vision applications. This period built upon earlier work in pattern recognition by refining algorithms and scaling up to larger datasets, solidifying deep learning's role as a dominant paradigm in visual data analysis.

representative_papers.title: Rich Feature Hierarchies for Accurate Object Detection and Semantic Segmentation
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a novel algorithm, R-CNN, that significantly enhances object detection and semantic segmentation performance on the PASCAL VOC dataset by over 30% compared to previous methods. It leverages high-capacity convolutional neural networks for region proposals and emphasizes the benefits of supervised pre-training with limited labeled data, providing insights into the learned feature hierarchies.

Topic: pattern recognition, computer science, machine learning, fuzzy set, image analysis, information fusion, accurate object detection, feature detection, cognitive science, object detection, data science, object categorization, computational imaging, localization, deep learning, machine vision, rich feature hierarchies, semantic segmentation, object recognition, computer vision, scene analysis

representative_papers.title: Going deeper with convolutions
representative_papers.abstract:
The article introduces a deep convolutional neural network architecture called Inception, which achieved state-of-the-art results in the ImageNet Large-Scale Visual Recognition Challenge 2014. It emphasizes the efficient use of computational resources through a carefully designed network structure, exemplified by GoogLeNet, a 22-layer model that enhances classification and detection capabilities while maintaining a constant computational budget.

Topic: image analysis, computational imaging, computer science, information fusion, convolutional neural network, large language model, deep reinforcement learning, machine learning, applied mathematics, sparse neural network, data science, neural computation, deep learning, computational intelligence, machine learning research, deepfakes, neural network (machine learning), machine vision

representative_papers.title: Very Deep Convolutional Networks for Large-Scale Image Recognition
representative_papers.abstract:
The article explores the impact of increasing the depth of convolutional networks on accuracy in large-scale image recognition, demonstrating that using very small (3x3) convolution filters can significantly enhance performance with networks of 16-19 weight layers. The findings contributed to a successful submission in the ImageNet Challenge 2014, securing top placements, and the authors have made their best-performing models publicly available to support further research in deep learning and computer vision.

Topic: digital image processing, automatic classification, deep convolutional networks, computer science, machine learning research, deep learning, pattern recognition, machine vision, image representation, large-scale image recognition, large-scale datasets, computational imaging, machine learning, data science, cognitive science, computational intelligence, convolutional neural network, feature detection, unsupervised machine learning, image analysis

representative_papers.title: Fully convolutional networks for semantic segmentation
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the development and application of fully convolutional networks (FCNs) for semantic segmentation, demonstrating that these networks can outperform state-of-the-art methods by processing images of arbitrary sizes and producing correspondingly-sized outputs. It highlights the architecture's ability to combine features from different layers for improved segmentation accuracy and reports significant performance improvements on benchmark datasets like PASCAL VOC and NYUDv2.

Topic: pattern recognition, computer science, machine learning, image segmentation, image analysis, information fusion, convolutional neural network, convolutional networks, cognitive science, data science, computational imaging, scene understanding, deep learning, machine learning research, machine vision, semantic segmentation, medical image computing, feature extraction, computer vision, scene analysis

representative_papers.title: Learning Hierarchical Features for Scene Labeling
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a novel method for scene labeling that utilizes a multiscale convolutional network to extract dense feature vectors from raw pixel data, enabling the automatic categorization of each pixel in an image. This approach enhances representation by capturing various attributes such as texture and shape, while achieving high accuracy on benchmark datasets and significantly improving processing speed compared to existing methods.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, computational imaging, image classification, supervised learning, scene understanding, hierarchical classification, computer vision, machine learning, scene analysis, data science, hierarchical features, deep learning, scene labeling, machine vision

original_period_characterizations.topic_description: During 2017-2021, deep learning witnessed significant advancements primarily focused on improving computer vision tasks. Notable papers such as "Very Deep Convolutional Networks for Large-Scale Image Recognition" (2014) and "Going deeper with convolutions" (2015) exemplify the trend towards creating more complex neural network architectures to enhance feature extraction from visual data, while "Fully convolutional networks for semantic segmentation" (2015) demonstrates another key development in making vision models fully trainable end-to-end.

representative_papers.title: Mask R-CNN
representative_papers.abstract:
The article introduces Mask R-CNN, a versatile framework for object instance segmentation that enhances the Faster R-CNN model by adding a branch for predicting segmentation masks alongside bounding box detection. It demonstrates superior performance across various tasks, including segmentation and keypoint detection, while maintaining efficiency and ease of training, positioning it as a strong baseline for future research in instance-level tasks.

Topic: human identification, biomedical imaging, pattern recognition, automatic classification, computational imaging, information fusion, machine vision, mask r-cnn, neural network (machine learning), cognitive science, computer science, convolutional neural network, machine learning, feature detection, object detection, deep learning, data science, image analysis

representative_papers.title: Feature Pyramid Networks for Object Detection
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the development of Feature Pyramid Networks (FPN) for object detection, which enhances the ability to recognize objects at various scales using a top-down architecture with lateral connections. The proposed method demonstrates significant improvements in detection performance on the COCO benchmark while maintaining practical computational efficiency, making it a state-of-the-art solution in the field of computer vision.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, feature pyramid networks, computer vision, machine learning, feature detection, object detection, object categorization, deep learning, image representation, feature construction, machine vision, feature (computer vision)

representative_papers.title: Faster R-CNN: Towards Real-Time Object Detection with Region Proposal Networks
representative_papers.abstract:
The article introduces Faster R-CNN, a novel object detection framework that utilizes Region Proposal Networks (RPN) to generate high-quality object proposals with minimal computational cost, significantly improving detection speed and accuracy. By integrating full-image convolutional features and leveraging neural attention mechanisms, the system achieves state-of-the-art performance on benchmark datasets while maintaining a real-time frame rate.

Topic: pattern recognition, computer science, machine learning, image analysis, information fusion, cognitive science, object detection, data science, computational imaging, scene understanding, localization, deep learning, machine vision, region proposal networks, object tracking, object recognition, computer vision, scene analysis, vehicular technology

representative_papers.title: ImageNet classification with deep convolutional neural networks
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the development and training of a deep convolutional neural network that achieved significant improvements in image classification accuracy on the ImageNet dataset, achieving top-1 and top-5 error rates of 37.5% and 17.0%, respectively. It highlights the network's architecture, including its use of dropout for regularization and efficient GPU implementation, and notes its success in the ILSVRC-2012 competition.

Topic: computer science, data classification, machine learning, intelligent classification, automatic classification, image analysis, convolutional neural network, biomedical imaging, data science, image representation, computational imaging, deep learning, machine learning research, digital image processing, medical image computing, imagenet classification, health science, neural network (machine learning), image classification

representative_papers.title: Densely Connected Convolutional Networks
representative_papers.abstract:
The article introduces Dense Convolutional Networks (DenseNet), a novel architecture that enhances convolutional networks by connecting each layer to every other layer in a feed-forward manner, resulting in improved accuracy, efficiency, and reduced parameters. The authors demonstrate DenseNet's effectiveness on several object recognition benchmarks, achieving significant performance gains over existing state-of-the-art methods while minimizing memory and computational requirements.

Topic: computer science, convolutional neural network, convolutional networks, computer vision, machine learning, deep learning, large-scale datasets, neural network (machine learning), machine vision

final_period_characterizations.topic_label: Deep Learning for Pattern Recognition in Computer Vision
final_period_characterizations.topic_description: During the 1990-1994 period, deep learning research was characterized by intense exploration of neural networks for pattern recognition tasks. The publication "Neural Networks for Pattern Recognition" (1994) exemplifies this focus on supervised learning algorithms applied to complex data analysis problems in image processing. Simultaneously, studies like "Eigenfaces for Recognition" (1991) demonstrated the viability of dimensionality reduction techniques such

representative_papers.title: C4.5: Programs for Machine Learning
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses "C4.5: Programs for Machine Learning," a comprehensive guide by Ross Quinlan that details the C4.5 algorithm for classification in machine learning. It covers the implementation of the algorithm, including source code, usage notes, and case studies, while emphasizing its effectiveness in creating decision trees and if-then rules for accurate data classification.

Topic: pattern recognition, computer science, computational learning theory, supervised learning, machine learning tool, machine learning, data science, computational intelligence, deep learning, statistics, knowledge discovery, machine learning research, automatic classification, automated machine learning, data mining

representative_papers.title: Neural networks for pattern recognition
representative_papers.abstract:
This article provides a comprehensive overview of feed-forward neural networks in the context of statistical pattern recognition, covering essential concepts, modeling techniques, error functions, and learning algorithms. It serves as a valuable resource for those in fields such as computer science, machine learning, and data science, featuring over 100 exercises to enhance understanding.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, convolutional neural network, neural architecture search, machine learning, recurrent neural network, sparse neural network, cognitive science, temporal pattern recognition, data science, computational intelligence, deep learning, neural networks, machine learning research, neural network (machine learning), machine vision

representative_papers.title: Eigenfaces for Recognition
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the development of a near-real-time facial recognition system that utilizes a two-dimensional approach to identify individuals by comparing their facial features to a database of known faces, leveraging eigenfaces as a method for efficient image representation and recognition. The system is designed to operate effectively within practical performance requirements and can learn new features in an unsupervised manner using neural network architecture.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, computational imaging, character recognition, machine learning, applied mathematics, data science, spectral theory, deep learning, image representation, machine learning research, facial recognition system, human identification, machine vision, digital image processing, facial expression recognition, face detection

representative_papers.title: The rapid generation of mutation data matrices from protein sequences
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents an efficient method for generating mutation data matrices from large protein sequence datasets using a peptide-based sequence comparison algorithm, enabling rapid clustering and alignment of sequences. This approach allows for the quick processing of extensive databases, such as SWISS-PROT, and updates standard mutation matrices that have not been revised in over a decade.

Topic: mutation data matrices, next-generation sequencing, molecular biology, matrix biology, protein sequences, bioinformatics, systems biology, mutation-based testing, gene expression, biostatistics, computational biology, deep learning, structural bioinformatics, genomics, machine learning research, rapid generation, sequence alignment, protein science, genome biology, sequence analysis, molecular informatics

representative_papers.title: The New Second Generation: Segmented Assimilation and its Variants
representative_papers.abstract:
The article explores the concept of segmented assimilation in the context of the new second generation of immigrants in the United States, highlighting the unique challenges and diverse outcomes they face in adapting to American society. It presents contemporary data and empirical case studies to illustrate the varying modes of incorporation and the resources that influence their integration experiences.

Topic: data science, data assimilation, deep learning, machine learning

final_period_characterizations.topic_label: Deep Learning for Computer Vision Pattern Recognition
final_period_characterizations.topic_description: During the period spanning from 1995 to 1998, deep learning research was primarily focused on advancing neural network-based approaches for pattern recognition tasks in computer vision. This era saw significant contributions such as 'Neural Networks: A Comprehensive Foundation' (1998) and 'Neural Networks for Pattern Recognition' (1995), which provided a thorough mathematical understanding of the field, building upon earlier foundational work like 'Understanding Face Recognition'. Additionally, papers addressing cognitive science aspects and recurrent neural networks, such as 'Bidirectional Recurrent Neural Networks' (1997), highlighted the growing interest in modeling complex data analysis processes. Research on face recognition systems was further examined in 'Human and machine recognition of faces: a survey' (1995), demonstrating how deep learning techniques were being applied to real-world problems like visual attention, thereby solidifying its role as a crucial method for analyzing and interpreting complex sensory information.

representative_papers.title: Neural Networks for Pattern Recognition
representative_papers.abstract:
This book offers a comprehensive exploration of feed-forward neural networks within the context of statistical pattern recognition, covering essential concepts, modeling techniques, and error minimization algorithms. It also addresses key topics such as learning generalization, data processing, and feature extraction, concluding with an extensive discussion on Bayesian applications in neural networks.

Topic: neural networks, pattern recognition, machine vision, neural architecture search, sparse neural network, neural network (machine learning), temporal pattern recognition, cognitive science, computational intelligence, computer science, recurrent neural network, convolutional neural network, machine learning, machine learning research, deep learning, data science, image analysis

representative_papers.title: Neural Networks: A Comprehensive Foundation
representative_papers.abstract:
"Neural Networks: A Comprehensive Foundation" offers an in-depth exploration of neural networks from an engineering perspective, covering essential topics such as learning processes, back-propagation, and VLSI implementation. This well-organized and accessible text is designed for professional engineers and graduate students, featuring practical examples, problems, and illustrations to reinforce key concepts in the field of neural computation and machine learning.

Topic: computer science, machine learning, comprehensive foundation, neural networks, neural computation, deep learning, neural network (machine learning), neuronal network

representative_papers.title: Human and machine recognition of faces: a survey
representative_papers.abstract:
This article provides a comprehensive survey of the literature on human and machine face recognition, highlighting the various applications, technical challenges, and research developments in the field over the past two decades. It emphasizes the lack of collaboration between psychophysics and engineering studies and reviews techniques for face segmentation, feature extraction, and classification methods.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, object recognition, computer vision, machine learning, cognitive science, deep learning, facial recognition system, vision recognition, machine vision, face detection, machine recognition, facial expression recognition

representative_papers.title: A model of saliency-based visual attention for rapid scene analysis
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a visual attention system modeled after primate behavior and neuronal architecture, which creates a topographical saliency map by combining multiscale image features. This system efficiently identifies and selects prominent locations in a scene for rapid analysis, enhancing scene understanding and interpretation in computer vision applications.

Topic: computer science, vision recognition, information fusion, scene analysis, scene interpretation, cognitive science, vision language model, data science, deep learning, pattern recognition, machine learning, computer vision, computational imaging, scene understanding, rapid scene analysis, saliency-based visual attention, machine vision, image analysis, image representation

representative_papers.title: Bidirectional recurrent neural networks
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the development of bidirectional recurrent neural networks (BRNNs), which enhance traditional RNNs by allowing simultaneous training in both forward and backward time directions. It presents experimental results demonstrating that BRNNs outperform other methods in regression classification tasks on artificial data and phoneme recognition from the TIMIT database, while also facilitating efficient estimation of conditional posterior probabilities for complete symbol sequences.

Topic: computer science, machine learning, recurrent neural network, neural computation, computational neuroscience, deep learning, neural network (machine learning)

final_period_characterizations.topic_label: Advancements in Deep Learning for Computer Vision
final_period_characterizations.topic_description: During 1999-2003, deep learning research continued to advance through multiple paradigms including neural networks applied to computer vision tasks. Papers like 'Eigenfaces for Recognition' (1994) were further developed and refined during this period. The focus shifted towards handling challenges such as class imbalance in datasets with the introduction of techniques like SMOTE.

representative_papers.title: SMOTE: Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique (SMOTE) as a method for improving classifier performance on imbalanced datasets, where minority classes are underrepresented. It highlights the effectiveness of combining over-sampling of minority classes with under-sampling of majority classes to enhance sensitivity and achieve better results in classification tasks, particularly in terms of the Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) curve.

Topic: sampling (statistics), sampling, monte carlo sampling, sampling technique, applied statistics, machine learning, data heterogeneity, biostatistics, data science, deep learning, statistics, machine learning research, complex sample, data mining

representative_papers.title: Mean shift: a robust approach toward feature space analysis
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a non-parametric mean shift technique for analyzing complex multimodal feature spaces and identifying arbitrarily shaped clusters. It demonstrates the method's effectiveness through applications in low-level vision tasks, such as image segmentation and discontinuity-preserving smoothing, supported by extensive experimental results.

Topic: pattern recognition, computer science, machine learning, feature space analysis, mean shift, image analysis, information fusion, structure from motion, feature detection, data science, feature (computer vision), computational imaging, robust feature, deep learning, computational statistic, machine learning research, shift detection, machine vision, computer vision, applied mathematics

representative_papers.title: Multiresolution gray-scale and rotation invariant texture classification with local binary patterns
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a novel multiresolution approach for gray-scale and rotation invariant texture classification using local binary patterns, emphasizing the significance of "uniform" patterns in image analysis. It highlights the method's computational efficiency and robustness against variations, supported by experimental results demonstrating effective classification of simple texture patterns.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, image classification, hierarchical classification, computer vision, local binary patterns, multiresolution gray-scale, object categorization, deep learning, texture analysis, machine vision, digital image processing

representative_papers.title: Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems 14
representative_papers.abstract:
The article provides an overview of the proceedings from the 2001 Neural Information Processing Systems (NIPS) Conference, highlighting its interdisciplinary focus on neural computation and the high-quality research presented across various fields such as algorithms, cognitive science, and machine learning. It notes that only about 30 percent of submitted papers were accepted, underscoring the conference's commitment to excellence in the field.

Topic: computer science, artificial intelligence, machine learning, neural science, neural computation, computational intelligence, deep learning, machine learning research, neural network (machine learning), intelligent information processing, neural information

representative_papers.title: <tt>BLAT</tt>—The <tt>BLAST</tt>-Like Alignment Tool
representative_papers.abstract:
The article introduces BLAT, a new alignment tool that significantly enhances the speed and accuracy of mRNA/DNA and cross-species protein alignments in vertebrate genomes, achieving results 500 times faster than existing methods. It details BLAT's innovative use of K-mer indexing and its multi-stage alignment process, while also comparing its performance against other tools and discussing optimization strategies.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, information fusion, sequence analysis, clustering, data science, molecular biology, deep learning, network analysis, signal recognition, sequence alignment, representation analysis, sequence assembly

final_period_characterizations.topic_label: Deep Learning for Computer Vision Pattern Recognition
final_period_characterizations.topic_description: During 2004-2008, research in deep learning was heavily concentrated on enhancing neural network methods for computer vision tasks. Key papers like 'Reducing the Dimensionality of Data with Neural Networks' (2006) and 'A Fast Learning Algorithm for Deep Belief Nets' (2006) exemplified the focus on developing more efficient architectures, while works such as 'Best practices for convolutional neural networks applied to visual document analysis' (2005) showed practical applications in areas like object recognition. This period built upon earlier advancements by refining algorithms and addressing challenges specific to complex data representation and classification.

representative_papers.title: A Fast Learning Algorithm for Deep Belief Nets
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a fast learning algorithm for deep belief networks that utilizes complementary priors to address inference challenges in densely connected networks with multiple hidden layers. By employing a greedy layer-wise training approach and a fine-tuning process, the algorithm effectively models the joint distribution of handwritten digit images and their labels, outperforming traditional discriminative methods in classification tasks.

Topic: computer science, fast learning algorithm, deep belief nets, unsupervised machine learning, machine learning, computational intelligence, deep learning, neural network (machine learning)

representative_papers.title: Reducing the Dimensionality of Data with Neural Networks
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the use of multilayer neural networks, specifically autoencoders, for reducing high-dimensional data to low-dimensional representations, highlighting an effective initialization method that enhances their performance compared to traditional principal components analysis.

Topic: dimensionality reduction, data reduction, machine learning, neural networks, data science, deep learning, machine learning research, nonlinear dimensionality reduction, neural network (machine learning)

representative_papers.title: Best practices for convolutional neural networks applied to visual document analysis
representative_papers.abstract:
This article outlines best practices for applying convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to visual document analysis, emphasizing the importance of training on large datasets and the advantages of using convolutional architectures over fully connected networks. It provides a straightforward implementation approach that avoids complex techniques, demonstrating effective results through examples with MNIST digit images.

Topic: image analysis, computer science, information visualization, convolutional neural network, text recognition, computer vision, machine learning, visualization, best practices, cognitive science, data science, deep learning, image representation, machine learning research, holistic view, machine vision, visual document analysis, visual question answering

representative_papers.title: A performance evaluation of local descriptors
representative_papers.abstract:
This article evaluates the performance of various local descriptors used for image analysis, particularly those extracted by the Harris-Affine detector, by comparing their effectiveness in terms of recall and precision under different viewing conditions. The study highlights the superiority of an extended SIFT descriptor over the original, while also noting that SIFT-based descriptors generally perform best across different detectors, with steerable filters excelling among low-dimensional options.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, machine vision, content-based image retrieval, object recognition, image retrieval, computer vision, object detection, data science, deep learning, image representation, machine learning research, local descriptors, information retrieval, feature (computer vision)

representative_papers.title: PCA-SIFT: a more distinctive representation for local image descriptors
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses PCA-SIFT, an enhanced local image descriptor that improves upon the traditional SIFT algorithm by utilizing principal components analysis (PCA) for more distinctive and robust feature representation. The authors demonstrate that PCA-SIFT offers greater accuracy and efficiency in image retrieval and matching tasks compared to standard SIFT descriptors.

Topic: pattern recognition, computer science, principal component analysis, image analysis, information fusion, local image descriptors, feature detection, data science, image representation, distinctive representation, vision recognition, feature (computer vision), computational imaging, localization, deep learning, machine vision, digital image processing, object recognition, computer vision, geography

final_period_characterizations.topic_description: During 2009-2012, deep learning research focused on feature learning within computer vision tasks. The publication of 'Learning Multiple Layers of Features from Tiny Images' (2009) demonstrated how hierarchical representations could be learned from basic image data. Concurrently, papers like 'Convolutional Deep Belief Networks for Scalable Unsupervised Learning of Hierarchical Representations' (2009) showcased the potential of deep architectures to capture complex patterns in visual data.

representative_papers.title: Learning Multiple Layers of Features from Tiny Images
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the training of a multi-layer generative model for natural images using a dataset of millions of tiny color images, specifically focusing on Restricted Boltzmann Machines (RBMs) and Deep Belief Networks (DBNs) to learn effective image features and improve classification performance compared to raw pixel data. It highlights the challenges faced by previous attempts and emphasizes the use of the CIFAR-10 dataset for labeled image analysis.

Topic: image analysis, computational imaging, computer science, feature learning, computer vision, machine learning, tiny images, feature fusion, multiple layers, data science, knowledge discovery, deep learning, image representation, few-shot learning, machine vision, digital image processing, multiple instance learning

representative_papers.title: Learning Deep Architectures for AI
representative_papers.abstract:
The article explores the role of deep architectures in advancing artificial intelligence, emphasizing their necessity for learning complex functions and high-level abstractions in tasks like vision and language. It discusses recent developments in algorithms and architectures, particularly in the context of neural networks and belief networks, while highlighting the challenges and future directions in this evolving field.

Topic: machine learning, computer science, deep architectures, artificial intelligence, deep learning, ai architecture

representative_papers.title: Convolutional deep belief networks for scalable unsupervised learning of hierarchical representations
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the development of convolutional deep belief networks designed for scalable unsupervised learning of hierarchical representations, enabling effective processing of high-dimensional images. It highlights the model's ability to perform efficient probabilistic inference and learn high-level visual features from unlabeled natural scenes, demonstrating strong performance in various recognition tasks.

Topic: computer science, convolutional neural network, hierarchical classification, neuroscience, machine learning, unsupervised machine learning, hierarchical representations, data science, neural computation, deep learning, machine learning research, neural network (machine learning), scalable unsupervised learning

representative_papers.title: Context-Dependent Pre-Trained Deep Neural Networks for Large-Vocabulary Speech Recognition
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a novel context-dependent deep neural network (CD-DNN-HMM) model for large-vocabulary speech recognition, highlighting its effectiveness in improving accuracy over traditional Gaussian mixture models. Through robust pre-training and optimization techniques, the proposed model demonstrates significant performance enhancements on a challenging business search dataset, achieving notable reductions in error rates.

Topic: computer science, speech recognition, voice recognition, language model, natural language processing, speech processing, spoken language processing, machine learning, cognitive science, data science, language recognition, deep learning, speech communication, large-vocabulary speech recognition, speech technology, spoken language technology, language learning, speech corpus

representative_papers.title: Matrix Factorization Techniques for Recommender Systems
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the advantages of matrix factorization techniques over traditional nearest neighbor methods in recommender systems, highlighting their ability to integrate various types of information, such as implicit feedback and temporal effects, as demonstrated by the Netflix Prize competition.

Topic: computer science, ranking algorithm, machine learning, recommender system, cold-start problem, data science, deep learning, matrix factorization, machine learning research, principal component analysis, information retrieval, matrix factorization techniques, data mining

final_period_characterizations.topic_label: Advancements in Deep Learning for Computer Vision
final_period_characterizations.topic_description: During the period spanning from 2013 to 2016, deep learning experienced substantial advancements primarily focused on improving computer vision tasks. Notable papers such as "Very Deep Convolutional Networks for Large-Scale Image Recognition" (2014) and "Going deeper with convolutions" (2015) exemplify the trend towards creating more complex neural network architectures to enhance feature extraction from visual data, while "Fully convolutional networks for semantic segmentation" (2015) demonstrates another key development in making vision models fully trainable end-to-end. Additionally, papers like "Rich Feature Hierarchies for Accurate Object Detection and Semantic Segmentation" (2014) and "Learning Hierarchical Features for Scene Labeling" (2013) further validate the effectiveness of deep feature hierarchies across various computer vision applications. This period built upon earlier work in pattern recognition by refining algorithms and scaling up to larger datasets, solidifying deep learning's role as a dominant paradigm in visual data analysis.

representative_papers.title: Rich Feature Hierarchies for Accurate Object Detection and Semantic Segmentation
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a novel algorithm, R-CNN, that significantly enhances object detection and semantic segmentation performance on the PASCAL VOC dataset by over 30% compared to previous methods. It leverages high-capacity convolutional neural networks for region proposals and emphasizes the benefits of supervised pre-training with limited labeled data, providing insights into the learned feature hierarchies.

Topic: pattern recognition, computer science, machine learning, fuzzy set, image analysis, information fusion, accurate object detection, feature detection, cognitive science, object detection, data science, object categorization, computational imaging, localization, deep learning, machine vision, rich feature hierarchies, semantic segmentation, object recognition, computer vision, scene analysis

representative_papers.title: Going deeper with convolutions
representative_papers.abstract:
The article introduces a deep convolutional neural network architecture called Inception, which achieved state-of-the-art results in the ImageNet Large-Scale Visual Recognition Challenge 2014. It emphasizes the efficient use of computational resources through a carefully designed network structure, exemplified by GoogLeNet, a 22-layer model that enhances classification and detection capabilities while maintaining a constant computational budget.

Topic: image analysis, computational imaging, computer science, information fusion, convolutional neural network, large language model, deep reinforcement learning, machine learning, applied mathematics, sparse neural network, data science, neural computation, deep learning, computational intelligence, machine learning research, deepfakes, neural network (machine learning), machine vision

representative_papers.title: Very Deep Convolutional Networks for Large-Scale Image Recognition
representative_papers.abstract:
The article explores the impact of increasing the depth of convolutional networks on accuracy in large-scale image recognition, demonstrating that using very small (3x3) convolution filters can significantly enhance performance with networks of 16-19 weight layers. The findings contributed to a successful submission in the ImageNet Challenge 2014, securing top placements, and the authors have made their best-performing models publicly available to support further research in deep learning and computer vision.

Topic: digital image processing, automatic classification, deep convolutional networks, computer science, machine learning research, deep learning, pattern recognition, machine vision, image representation, large-scale image recognition, large-scale datasets, computational imaging, machine learning, data science, cognitive science, computational intelligence, convolutional neural network, feature detection, unsupervised machine learning, image analysis

representative_papers.title: Fully convolutional networks for semantic segmentation
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the development and application of fully convolutional networks (FCNs) for semantic segmentation, demonstrating that these networks can outperform state-of-the-art methods by processing images of arbitrary sizes and producing correspondingly-sized outputs. It highlights the architecture's ability to combine features from different layers for improved segmentation accuracy and reports significant performance improvements on benchmark datasets like PASCAL VOC and NYUDv2.

Topic: pattern recognition, computer science, machine learning, image segmentation, image analysis, information fusion, convolutional neural network, convolutional networks, cognitive science, data science, computational imaging, scene understanding, deep learning, machine learning research, machine vision, semantic segmentation, medical image computing, feature extraction, computer vision, scene analysis

representative_papers.title: Learning Hierarchical Features for Scene Labeling
representative_papers.abstract:
The article presents a novel method for scene labeling that utilizes a multiscale convolutional network to extract dense feature vectors from raw pixel data, enabling the automatic categorization of each pixel in an image. This approach enhances representation by capturing various attributes such as texture and shape, while achieving high accuracy on benchmark datasets and significantly improving processing speed compared to existing methods.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, computational imaging, image classification, supervised learning, scene understanding, hierarchical classification, computer vision, machine learning, scene analysis, data science, hierarchical features, deep learning, scene labeling, machine vision

final_period_characterizations.topic_description: During 2017-2021, deep learning witnessed significant advancements primarily focused on improving computer vision tasks. Notable papers such as "Very Deep Convolutional Networks for Large-Scale Image Recognition" (2014) and "Going deeper with convolutions" (2015) exemplify the trend towards creating more complex neural network architectures to enhance feature extraction from visual data, while "Fully convolutional networks for semantic segmentation" (2015) demonstrates another key development in making vision models fully trainable end-to-end.

representative_papers.title: Mask R-CNN
representative_papers.abstract:
The article introduces Mask R-CNN, a versatile framework for object instance segmentation that enhances the Faster R-CNN model by adding a branch for predicting segmentation masks alongside bounding box detection. It demonstrates superior performance across various tasks, including segmentation and keypoint detection, while maintaining efficiency and ease of training, positioning it as a strong baseline for future research in instance-level tasks.

Topic: human identification, biomedical imaging, pattern recognition, automatic classification, computational imaging, information fusion, machine vision, mask r-cnn, neural network (machine learning), cognitive science, computer science, convolutional neural network, machine learning, feature detection, object detection, deep learning, data science, image analysis

representative_papers.title: Feature Pyramid Networks for Object Detection
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the development of Feature Pyramid Networks (FPN) for object detection, which enhances the ability to recognize objects at various scales using a top-down architecture with lateral connections. The proposed method demonstrates significant improvements in detection performance on the COCO benchmark while maintaining practical computational efficiency, making it a state-of-the-art solution in the field of computer vision.

Topic: image analysis, pattern recognition, computer science, feature pyramid networks, computer vision, machine learning, feature detection, object detection, object categorization, deep learning, image representation, feature construction, machine vision, feature (computer vision)

representative_papers.title: Faster R-CNN: Towards Real-Time Object Detection with Region Proposal Networks
representative_papers.abstract:
The article introduces Faster R-CNN, a novel object detection framework that utilizes Region Proposal Networks (RPN) to generate high-quality object proposals with minimal computational cost, significantly improving detection speed and accuracy. By integrating full-image convolutional features and leveraging neural attention mechanisms, the system achieves state-of-the-art performance on benchmark datasets while maintaining a real-time frame rate.

Topic: pattern recognition, computer science, machine learning, image analysis, information fusion, cognitive science, object detection, data science, computational imaging, scene understanding, localization, deep learning, machine vision, region proposal networks, object tracking, object recognition, computer vision, scene analysis, vehicular technology

representative_papers.title: ImageNet classification with deep convolutional neural networks
representative_papers.abstract:
The article discusses the development and training of a deep convolutional neural network that achieved significant improvements in image classification accuracy on the ImageNet dataset, achieving top-1 and top-5 error rates of 37.5% and 17.0%, respectively. It highlights the network's architecture, including its use of dropout for regularization and efficient GPU implementation, and notes its success in the ILSVRC-2012 competition.

Topic: computer science, data classification, machine learning, intelligent classification, automatic classification, image analysis, convolutional neural network, biomedical imaging, data science, image representation, computational imaging, deep learning, machine learning research, digital image processing, medical image computing, imagenet classification, health science, neural network (machine learning), image classification

representative_papers.title: Densely Connected Convolutional Networks
representative_papers.abstract:
The article introduces Dense Convolutional Networks (DenseNet), a novel architecture that enhances convolutional networks by connecting each layer to every other layer in a feed-forward manner, resulting in improved accuracy, efficiency, and reduced parameters. The authors demonstrate DenseNet's effectiveness on several object recognition benchmarks, achieving significant performance gains over existing state-of-the-art methods while minimizing memory and computational requirements.

Topic: computer science, convolutional neural network, convolutional networks, computer vision, machine learning, deep learning, large-scale datasets, neural network (machine learning), machine vision
